overview.short: Gardnerella species are Gram-variable, facultatively anaerobic short rods associated with the vaginal microbiota.
overview.clinical_context: Most commonly linked to bacterial vaginosis, often as part of a polymicrobial biofilm.

field_notes.Gram Stain: Appears Gram-variable due to thin cell wall and staining inconsistency.
field_notes.Haemolysis: Beta haemolysis is best observed on human blood-containing media.
field_notes.Shape: Often described as pleomorphic short rods or coccobacilli.

key_differentiators.notes: Esculin positivity helps separate Gardnerella from curved anaerobic rods.
Beta haemolysis supports Gardnerella in vaginal isolates.

common_confusions.reason: Shared vaginal habitat but Lactobacillus is Gram-positive and non-haemolytic.
Associated with bacterial vaginosis but differs in motility and morphology.

when_to_question_identification: Strong Gram-positive cocci suggest Streptococcus or Enterococcus.
Motility or curved rods suggest Mobiluncus.
Strict anaerobic growth is inconsistent with Gardnerella.

recommended_next_tests.reason: Supports genus-level identification in vaginal isolates.
Enhances detection of characteristic beta haemolysis.
Preferred confirmation due to phenotypic overlap.
